facts.text: This is an appeal under S. 35L of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal under S. 35L of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

facts.text: The appeal is directed against the order dated 15-4-1988 of the Customs Excise and Gold Control Appellate Tribunal, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is directed against the order dated 15-4-1988 of the Customs Excise and Gold  Control  Appellate Tribunal, New Delhi.

facts.text: The appellant is the manufacturer of Hacksaw blades and Bandsaw Blades falling under Tariff Item No. 51-A iv of the Central Excise Tariff.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the manufacturer of Hacksaw blades and Bandsaw Blades falling under Tariff Item No. 51-A iv  of the Central Excise Tariff.

facts.text: The appellant filed a classification list as per Rule 173B of the Central Excise Rules 1944 on 26-3-1985 furnishing the tariff rate of 15 ad valorem by mistake instead of effective rates per Notification No. 85/85 CE dated 17-3-1985.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a classification list as per Rule 173B of the Central Excise Rules 1944 on 26-3-1985 in respect of their products furnishing the tariff rate of 15 ad valorem by mistake instead of furnishing the effective rates of duty as per Notification No. 85/85 CE dated 17-3-1985.

facts.text: Aggregate value of the clearance in the preceding year i.e. 1984-85 did not exceed Rs. 75 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The aggregate value of the clearance in the preceding year i.e. 1984-85 did number exceed Rs. 75 lakhs.

facts.text: Effective rates of duty: first clearance up to Rs. 7.5 lakhs nil, next clearance of Rs. 7.5 lakhs at 3.75 ad valorem.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of first clearance up to an aggregate value number exceeding Rs. 7.5 lakhs, the effective rates of duty is nil and in the case of next clearance of Rs. 7.5 lakhs, the duty is 3.75 ad valorem.

facts.text: Assistant Collector of Central Excise, Hyderabad, approved the tariff rate 15 ad valorem on 3-6-1985.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector of Central Excise, Hyderabad, approved the tariff rate 15 ad valorem on 3-6-1985 instead of the above effective rates as the appellant did number claim the exemption as per Notification No. 85/85 CE dated 17-3-1985 due to ignorance.

facts.text: Revised classification list with effective rates filed on 31-10-1985 with retrospective effect from 26-3-1985.

anchor.surface_text: A revised classification list with the effective rates in respect of the products with retrospective effect from 26-3-1985 was filed on 31-10-1985.

facts.text: The revised classification list was approved.

anchor.surface_text: The revised classification list was approved.

facts.text: Appellant paid excess Rs. 2,55,172.55 as excise duty from 1-4-1985 to 31-8-1985.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that they had paid excess Rs. 2,55,172.55 from 1-4-1985 to 31-8-1985 as excise duty.

facts.text: Appellant made refund application under S. 11B on 30-10-1985.

anchor.surface_text: They made an application for refund as per rule under S. 11B of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 on 30-10-1985.

facts.text: Assistant Collector order dated 13-12-1985 sanctioned refund claim only partly.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector of Central Excise by his order dated 13-12-1985 sanctioned the refund claim only partly.

facts.text: Refund claim for period 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985 rejected as time barred.

anchor.surface_text: For the period from 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985, the refund claim was rejected on the ground that the same was time barred.

facts.text: Assistant Collector held relevant date under S.11B is date of payment of duty by adjustment in personal ledger account.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector held that the refund claim for the period 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985 was time barred for the reason that under S. 11B, the relevant date for preferring the claim for a case such as that of the appellant was the date of payment of duty and, according to him, the duty had been paid by adjustment in the personal ledger account as and when goods were removed.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded that relevant date is date of assessment of RT-12 Returns filed monthly.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the appellant is that mere detailing in the personal ledger account should number be taken as the starting point for limitation and the relevant date should be the date on which RT-12 Returns which are filed on a monthly basis are assessed.

facts.text: Order of Assistant Collector confirmed by Collector of Central Excise Appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Assistant Collector was companyfirmed in the appeal by the Collector of Central Excise  Appeals .

facts.text: Further appeal to the Tribunal was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The further appeal to the Tribunal was also unsuccessful.

facts.text: RT-12 Return for April 1985 filed on 8-5-1985 and assessed on 29-10-1985.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the RT-12 Return for the month of April, 1985 was filed on 8-5-1985 and the same was assessed on 29-10-1985.

facts.text: Classification list not approved till 3-6-85.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the classification list filed by the appellant for the period 1-4-85 to 27-4-85 was number approved till 3-6-85.

facts.text: Between 1-4-1985 and 3-6-1985, appellant cleared goods by debiting duty in personal ledger account provisionally.

anchor.surface_text: In the present, case between 1st April, 1975 1985?  When the classification list was filed and 3rd June, 1985 when the list was approved, the assessee was clearing the goods by determining the duty himself and debiting the amount of duty in his personal ledger account.

facts.text: Clearances between 1st April and 3rd June 1985 were under provisional assessment procedure.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the clearance of goods made by the appellant between 1st April and 3rd of June, 1985 were in accordance with the procedure for provisional assessment.

facts.text: Clause (e) of Explanation to S.11B applies as duty paid provisionally.

anchor.surface_text: In such a situation cl.  e  of para  B  of the Explanation under S. 11B will be attracted.

facts.text: Refund application filed on 30th October 1985 not time barred.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the refund application had been filed on the 30th of October, 1985. It cannot, therefore, be said to be time barred.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, appellant entitled to full refund.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal has therefore to be allowed holding the appellant is entitled to the full amount and there is numberbar of limitation as found by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Appellant raised alternative contention that clause e applies.

anchor.surface_text: Before us, however, learned companynsel for the assessee has raised an alternative companytention. According to the appellant it is clause  e  which is applicable in the case whereas the companytention of the respondent is that clause  f  is attracted.
S. 35L of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

issues.text: as to the starting point of limitation for filing an application under S. 11B of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision in the appeal is as to the starting point of limitation for filing an application under S. 11B of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the appellant is that mere detailing in the personal ledger account should number be taken as the starting point for limitation and the relevant date should be the date on which RT-12 Returns which are filed on a monthly basis are assessed.

arguments.claim: Debit entry in personal ledger account constitutes effective payment of duty under clause (f) of Explanation to S.11B

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contention before the authorities was that the date of assessment would be the date of payment of duty within the meaning of clause f above. We agree with the learned Solicitor General that this argument is number tenable. Where an assessee maintains a personal ledger account, duty is paid by way of debit therein and goes to reduce the amount of deposit paid by the assessee. It is number a mere adjustment entry it is effective payment.

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted for non-provisional payments but rejected for pre-approval period as provisional under clause (e)

arguments.court_reasoning: Pre-approval self-removal clearances treated as provisional attracting clause (e)

arguments.claim: Clearances between 1-4-1985 and 3-6-1985 were under provisional assessment procedure per R.173B(2A), R.173CC, R.9B equivalent via self-removal and PLA debit, attracting clause (e) of S.11B Explanation; refund filed 30-10-1985 within time from 29-10-1985 assessment

holdings.text: Where an assessee maintains a personal ledger account, duty is paid by way of debit therein and goes to reduce the amount of deposit paid by the assessee. It is not a mere adjustment entry it is effective payment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contention before the authorities was that the date of assessment would be the date of payment of duty within the meaning of clause f above. We agree with the learned Solicitor General that this argument is number tenable. Where an assessee maintains a personal ledger account, duty is paid by way of debit therein and goes to reduce the amount of deposit paid by the assessee. It is number a mere adjustment entry it is effective payment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Debit in personal ledger account reduces the deposit and constitutes effective payment of duty under clause (f), not mere detailing or adjustment; agrees with Solicitor General rejecting appellant's plea for RT-12 assessment date.

holdings.text: The clearance of goods made by the appellant between 1st April and 3rd of June, 1985 were in accordance with the procedure for provisional assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the clearance of goods made by the appellant between 1st April and 3rd of June, 1985 were in accordance with the procedure for provisional assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under self-removal procedure (Chapter VII-A, Rules 173B(2A), 173CC), pre-approval clearances by self-determination and PLA debit equivalent to provisional assessment under R.9B (no bond needed due to PLA balance sufficient to cover duty).

holdings.text: In such a situation cl. e of para B of the Explanation under S. 11B will be attracted.

anchor.surface_text: In such a situation cl. e of para B of the Explanation under S. 11B will be attracted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisional duty payments under self-removal pre-approval attract clause (e) of Explanation to S.11B (relevant date: adjustment after final assessment), not clause (f).

holdings.text: It is, therefore, only from the date of this assessment that time bar in S. 11B will operate. In the present case the refund application had been filed on the 30th of October, 1985. It cannot, therefore, be said to be time barred.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the refund application had been filed on the 30th of October, 1985. It cannot, therefore, be said to be time barred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: RT-12 for April 1985 assessed 29-10-1985; refund filed 30-10-1985 within 6 months from relevant date under clause (e).

holdings.text: The appeal has therefore to be allowed holding the appellant is entitled to the full amount and there is no bar of limitation as found by the Tribunal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on application of clause (e), lower authorities erred; appellant entitled to full refund of excess duty paid.
